Award.AbstractNarration:
Searches for evidence for new physics beyond the Standard Model can be addressed through direct searches at the Energy Frontier at High Energy Colliding Beam Facilities such as the LHC and through a complementary technique of indirect searches at the Intensity Frontier, in experimental measurements of very-rare decay modes of known particles. This project focuses on continued research with the NA62 experiment at CERN, which is a measurement of the rare decay of the charge K meson through the process, K+ -> pi+ nu nubar. This decay is well-predicted in the Standard Model of Particle Physics, and a precision experimental measurement of the actual rate could provide evidence for new physics, if the observed rate differs significantly from the theoretical prediction. The experimental challenge is occasioned by the very small branching fraction predicted by the Standard Model for this decay mode of 0.85 x 10-10. Despite its small size, the GMU group is engaged in all aspects of NA62, with responsibilities in event trigger logic, trigger hardware and front-end electronics communication, slow controls, CEDAR (a special differential Cherenkov counter for the detection of kaons in the beam line, for which GMU has made significant contributions) and Muon Veto hardware components.

The George Mason group is making an impressive effort in broadening the participation in fundamental research at the intensity frontier, through its participation in QuarkNet and through a separate NSF IRES (International Research Experience for Students) grant that brings up to five undergraduates to CERN each summer, with applicants selected from a consortium of universities and colleges in the Washington DC Metropolitan Area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The George Mason University (GMU) experimental particle physics group supported by this grant consists of a principal investigator (PI), a graduate student, two undergraduate students, and two consultants (retired physicists).  It participates in the NA62 experiment at CERN, which intends to measure the rate of an ultra-rare decay (charged-pion + 2 neutrinos) of the charged kaon, the lightest particle containing a single strange quark.  A quality measurement will, if in agreement with prediction, increase knowledge of a number of fundamental parameters of the Standard Model, or, if not, provide a glimpse into physics beyond that model.  A number of alternative models predict different rates.  Other investigations accessible to the experiment include tests of lepton universality and searches for lepton number and lepton flavor violation, which might help explain the preponderance of matter (as opposed to anti-matter) in the universe. The group's primary contributions to the experiment during the period covered by this grant include event trigger logic, trigger hardware and front-end electronics communication, on-line software, and sub-detector hardware components.  The group furthermore offers undergraduate students first-hand internship experiences, trains graduate students for STEM careers, and promotes physics and more general scientific knowledge.

Intellectual Merit

The GMU group contributed to the construction and commissioning of CERN experiment NA62 (Ultra-Rare Kaon Decays), in particular to the trigger system, front-end electronics, several sub-detectors and databases, and on-line, simulation, and analysis code.  The PI worked on the design of the trigger system and sub-detector hardware, on-line utilities, and databases. Graduate students worked on front-end electronics, simulations of the beam line, sub-detector installation, detector performance evaluation software, and data analysis.  Undergraduate students developed diagnostic and calibration tools and readout software for the electromagnetic calorimeter, helped with the installation and commissioning of the third layer of the muon veto system, extended the on-line system to include an electronic checklist and the capacity for remote, real-time monitoring of the experiment, and simulated and tested trigger algorithms. Consultants worked on muon detection, the collaboration’s editorial board, trigger algorithms, and data analysis.

The NA62 collaboration collected data in 2007 with the NA48 detector array.  Analyses of these data led to two published papers.

  1. Precision Measurement of the Ratio of the Charged Kaon Leptonic Decay Rates, C.Lazzeroni, et al., Phys. Lett. B 719 (2013), pg. 326, arXiv:1212.4012 [hep-ex], set the world standard on the measurement, a key test of the Standard Model. The results agreed with the Standard Model prediction at the 10% level, although that prediction is thought to be good to the 4% level.
  2. Study of the K ± to π ± γγ decay by the NA62 experiment, C.Lazzeroni, et al., Phys. Lett. B 732C (2014), pg. 65, arXiv:1402.4334 [hep-ex], is of interest in the context of Chiral Perturbation Theory, with which the results agree at a level that might prompt further theoretical consideration.

The following NA62 internal notes were produced by GMU group members:

  1. NA62-12-06, “NA62 Electronic Logbook”
  2. NA62-12-09, “Liquid Krypton Calorimeter Readout Software Update”
  3. NA62-13-02, “Detector Preparation and Performance Analysis of the Muon Veto Three in NA62”
  4. NA62-13-03, “Level 0 Trigger Processor Run Control Implementation”
